headline: Sokoto govt denies alleged diversion of N189bn

headline: Gombe launches app to aid universal health coverage
summarized_story:
Gombe State Governor, Muhammadu Yahaya has launched a mobile application to encourage Universal Health Coverage across all strata.
According to him, since the takeoff of the initiative about 60,000 state civil servants, with their dependants have been enrolled and more than 25,000 poor and vulnerable accessing health care services in the state.
He said GoHealth ICT framework and blueprint would enable the state to leverage current and future ICT investments toward building an integrated health information infrastructure and greatly contribute to universal healthcare coverage.
Yahaya said, “In order to accelerate our drive towards achieving Universal Health Coverage in the state, our administration adopted innovative use of ICT for health in order to improve service delivery, ensure responsiveness, increase access, expand coverage and offer financial risk protection to our people.
“From the demonstration of the GoHealth mobile App we just witnessed, it is clear that the App is user-friendly, safe, and secure.

headline: Jubilant supporters receive Onoh back to Enugu
summarized_story:

Addressing the supporters, at the airport, Onoh told them, it was for the security, welfare and greater good of the people of Enugu state that makes him aspire to lead the state from 2023, stating that he has much at stake coming from a background that sacrificed for Enugu state, which he said was a covenant than selfish gains.
He also said he would redevelop community primary and secondary schools, and neighbourhood information centres in all layouts including fitness centres and libraries.
According to him: “Enugu state deserves a continuity of the Ugwuanyi inclusive administration.
From the airport, Onoh’s train moved to see Governor Ugwuanyi at the state government house, after which they move to his country home, Enugu-Ngwo.

headline: Court Convicts 73-year-old Man for Falsification of Vehicle Documents in Kwara
summarized_story:
Hammed Shittu in IlorinA Magistrate Court in Ilorin, the Kwara State capital, has convicted a 73-year-old trader, Bashir Alabi, for falsification of vehicle documents.
Alabi was handed over to the police for investigation having confirmed by the Kwara State Internal Revenue Service (KW-IRS) Motor Licencing Authority (MLA) office at Pake, Ilorin, that vehicle documents presented for processing by him were fake.
The additional three suspects were nabbed by the Monitoring Unit of the state Police Command for having incriminating documents in their possession and for their involvement in the trade of printing and selling fake Kwara State vehicle documents.
A further investigation by the police also established the recovery of forged state vehicle documents from the shop of one Jamiu, who is now at large.
Having established a case of forgery and conspiracy by the police, all suspects were arraigned before Chief Magistrate A.M Ibrahim.

headline: BREAKING: Lawless Nigeria Police Re-arrest Enslaved 21-year-old Woman, Glory Okolie Weeks After Release From Suleja Prison
summarized_story:
The Nigerian police have arrested a 21-year-old woman, Glory Okolie who only got out of the Suleja correctional centre in Niger State last week after more than eight months of incarceration.
SaharaReporters learnt that Okolie was arrested by the Imo State Police Command acting through the Divisional Police Officer of Shell Police Station.
SaharaReporters on November 23, 2021, reported that a Federal High Court sitting in Abuja granted bail to Gloria Okolie in the sum of N150 million with two sureties.
She was later transferred to Abuja, despite efforts by her family members to secure her release.
Okolie was later released on bail.

headline: Ozekhome: N’assembly tried to amend constitution illegally with section 84(12) of Electoral Act
summarized_story:
Mike Ozekhome, human rights lawyer, says the national assembly acted beyond its powers in its amendment of section 84(12) of the Electoral Act.
In a statement on Thursday, Ozekhome said the judge “scored the bull’s eye in striking down the offensive subsection 12 of section 84 of the new Electoral Act in Suit No.
She actually extended it to “any political appointee, political or public office holder”, as envisaged (according to these critics) in sections 84 and 318 of the 1999 Constitution.
“Why would the attorney-general seek to delete the offensive section 84 (12) as ordered by the Judge?
In a different twist, Ozekhome drew attention to section 84 (15) of the Electoral Act which he described as “more worrisome and dangerous”.
